What Is MOFA Attestation?

MOFA Attestation stands for Ministry of Foreign Affairs Attestation. It’s the final step in the legalization process of documents meant to be used in another country. Once the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) attests your document, it officially confirms that your document is genuine and can be accepted by UAE authorities.

Whether you are applying for a job, a visa, or planning to study in the UAE, your certificates must go through MOFA attestation. This is why MOFA Attestation UAE is one of the most commonly requested services by professionals and families moving to the region.
At Pro Attestation, we handle every stage — from pre-verification to final MOFA stamping — so you don’t have to worry about paperwork, queues, or missing seals.
Why Is MOFA Attestation Important?
Without MOFA attestation, your documents hold no legal value in the UAE. It is required for:

items: Employment in the UAE – All educational and professional certificates must be attested before submission to an employer.
Higher Education Admissions – Universities in the UAE require attested educational documents to confirm authenticity.
Family Visa Processing – Marriage and birth certificates must be attested to prove relationships when applying for dependent visas.
Business and Legal Documents – For companies establishing offices or signing contracts in the UAE, MOFA attestation ensures commercial documents are valid.

content.text: In short, MOFA Attestation acts as the UAE government’s official confirmation that your document is legitimate.

Step-by-Step Process of MOFA Attestation
Understanding the steps helps you see why professional support matters. Here’s how it works:
Step 1: Notary Attestation
The document is first verified by a local notary in the home country to confirm its authenticity.
Step 2: State or HRD Attestation
Next, the State Home Department or Human Resource Department (HRD) verifies educational or personal documents.
Step 3: MEA Attestation
The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) then authenticates the document on a national level.
Step 4: UAE Embassy Attestation
The document is then attested by the UAE Embassy in your home country to make it acceptable in the UAE.
Step 5: MOFA Attestation
Finally, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in the UAE validates the document. This final step makes it legally recognized for all official purposes.
